title: Stocks Rise After Wild Surge on Wall Street; Major banks reported earnings ahead of the bell, including JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo
text:
Big moves in U.S. stocks have become a fixture of this year's market. The S&P 500 has moved 2.5% or more in either direction during about 1 out of every 10 trading days this year. But Thursday's roughly 5% intraday swing was one that caught many investors by surprise and served as a reminder of how quickly traders can be caught offside when volatility strikes this year.

Early Friday morning, the rally in U.S. markets had rippled across the globe. Major indexes in Europe and Asia jumped. China's Shanghai Composite posted its biggest one-day rise since April, while Japan's Nikkei 225 saw its biggest rise since March. Riskier assets including cryptocurrencies also advanced. In recent trading, bitcoin climbed 2.2% from its 5 p.m. ET Thursday level to about $19,814.

Many investors on Friday morning looked to earnings from America's big banks for clues on the trajectory of the economy and about where markets might be headed next. JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo and Morgan Stanley each reported a fall in profits. JPMorgan's loss came as the nation's biggest bank built up its defenses for a potential recession. Its stock rose 1.4% premarket, while Wells Fargo rose 2.8%. Morgan Stanley bucked the trend, falling 1.2%.

Meanwhile, many on Wall Street were still searching for explanations for Thursday's rebound, which came after U.S. core inflation, or inflation excluding energy and food, accelerated to a new four-decade high in September. Stocks initially tumbled after the report, fearing it meant that the Federal Reserve would need to keep lifting interest rates aggressively to contain pricing pressures. They then reversed their losses, with a rally gaining steam as the day continued.

Some on Wall Street tried to find silver linings in the inflation report to explain the move. They posited that because shelter costs—which have a large weighting on inflation data—are factored in on a lagging basis, inflation in real time might not be so bad, thanks to falling rent prices recently.

Others, however, suggested the rally was instead purely technical, and was instead likely driven, in part, by a so-called short-covering rally, a phenomenon that occurs when bearish investors betting on stocks falling are forced to instead buy to contain losses on incorrect bets. The S&P 500 has tended to finish lower most days this year after consumer-price index data is released, suggesting many investors were anticipating another move lower Thursday.

"The conditions were ripe for a counterintuitive move, since we often see something like this when positioning is one-sided," said Jason Goepfert, president of Sundial Capital Research in an email.

Volatile swings Friday could leave the weekly performance of major indexes uncertain. As of Thursday's close, the S&P 500 and Dow had both recorded gains for the week, rising 0.8% and 2.5%, respectively. A weekly gain for both indexes would extend their winning streak into a second week.

In the bond market Friday, the yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note fell to 3.875%, from 3.952% Thursday. The yield on the two-year note, which is generally more sensitive to near-term interest-rate expectations, fell to 4.409%.

Many investors are also keeping an eye on U.K. markets, which have also swung wildly this week. On Friday, U.K. stocks and government bonds, or gilts, rallied after Prime Minister Liz Truss fired Treasury chief Kwasi Kwarteng, just weeks after he presented the largest tax cuts in a generation. The U.K.'s benchmark FTSE 100 climbed 1.7%. The yield on the 10-year U.K. government bond fell to 4.064%. Yields fall when bond prices rise.

The British pound fell 0.6% against the dollar.

Elsewhere overseas, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 gained 1.6%. In Asia, China's Shanghai Composite gained 1.8% while Japan's Nikkei 225 added about 3.3%.
